They also called for better training for police so that officers understand the full impact of domestic abuse, and move away from “a tickbox approach” to suicides.

articles.summary:
FTSE 100 company reports 6% fall in annual profits weeks after collapse of $260bn merger with Rio Tinto

Glencore is to give $2bn (£1.47bn) to shareholders after a turbulent year in which profits slumped and talks collapsed over a blockbuster $260bn merger with the fellow mining company Rio Tinto.

The FTSE 100 company announced the payout on Wednesday despite reporting that annual profits slipped 6% on the previous year to $13.5bn.

articles.title: Hazardous substances found in all headphones tested by ToxFREE project
articles.summary:
Substances include chemicals that can cause cancer, neurodevelopmental problems and the feminisation of males

You wear them at work, you wear them at play, you wear them to relax. You may even get sweaty in them at the gym.

But an investigation into headphones has found every single pair tested contained substances hazardous to human health, including chemicals that can cause cancer, neurodevelopmental problems and the feminisation of males.

Its ‘fibre checker’ tool confirmed I could have a connection, but a month later it changed its mind

My internet provider informed me by email that full fibre broadband had become available for my property, confirmed by Openreach’s “fibre checker” tool.

After a month, Openreach declared the connection uneconomical due to blockages in the conduits below the road.

articles.title: Why did I get a £100 parking fine when charging my electric car?
articles.summary:
The charger firm claimed the site operated 24 hours a day, but the parking operator had different ideas

I charged my electric car at the 24-hour Mer EV charging station in my local B&Q car park.

I then received a £100 parking charge notice (PCN) from the car park operator, Ocean Parking. It said no parking is allowed on the site between 9pm and 6am.

articles.title: Brushing fraud: Britons told to beware of mystery parcels as new scam soars
articles.summary: В Великобритании участились случаи мошенничества "brushing", когда злоумышленники, используя украденные личные данные, отправляют посылки с дешевыми украшениями.  Покупателям приходят неожиданные посылки, а после открытия обнаруживается, что они ничего не заказывали, а мошенники оставляют поддельные положительные отзывы.

articles.title: iPhone Air review: Apple’s pursuit of absolute thinness

Таким образом, устройство сводит суть iPhone к абсолютным основам в премиальном корпусе, заставляя задуматься о цене за легкость.
articles.original_description:
Ultra-slim and light smartphone feels special, but cuts to camera and battery may be too hard to ignore for most

The iPhone Air is a technical and design marvel that asks: how much are you willing to give up for a lightweight and ultra-slender profile?

Beyond the obvious engineering effort that has gone into creating one of the slimmest phones ever made, the Air is a reductive exercise that boils down the iPhone into the absolute essentials in a premium body.

Researchers find DMT – used in shamanic rituals – in tandem with psychotherapy has significant effect

People with major depressive disorder can see a rapid and lasting improvement after a single dose of the psychedelic drug dimethyltryptamine (DMT) when it is combined with psychotherapy, doctors have said.

A small clinical trial involving 34 people found that psychedelic-assisted therapy prompted a swift reduction in depressive symptoms that endured long after the drug had worn o

articles.title: Should we really all be taking magnesium supplements? – podcast
articles.summary:

Intermittent fasting is no better for shedding the pounds than conventional diets and is barely more effective than doing nothing, according to a major review of the scientific evidence.

articles.title: Why did Obama say aliens are real? | The Latest
articles.summary: Бывший президент США Барак Обама заявил в подкасте о своей вере в существование инопланетян, что вызвало широкий резонанс. Впоследствии он опубликовал заявление, подчеркнув, что у него нет доказательств существования внеземной жизни. Заявление Обамы вновь подогрело дискуссии о теориях заговора, связанных с Area 51.
articles.original_description:
Barack Obama has caused a frenzy after saying he thinks aliens are real during a podcast interview. The former US president was forced to release a statement clarifying he had not seen any evidence of extraterrestrials. There is a long-running conspiracy theory claiming the US government is hiding extraterrestrials at Area 51, a highly classified air force site in Nevada.

ISS now fully crewed after a medical issue forced the evacuation of four astronauts in January

SpaceX delivered the US, French and Russian astronauts a day after launching

articles.title: China’s Yangtze River shows signs of remarkable recovery after fishing ban
articles.summary:
Doubling of fish biomass and rebounding of endangered species shows government measures starting to work, biologists say

The Yangtze River in China, which has been in ecological decline for 70 years, is showing signs of recovery thanks to a sweeping fishing ban.

The ban was made more effective by the implementation of “evolutionary game theory”, which included finding alternative employment for fishers.

articles.title: What bots talk about when they think humans aren’t listening – podcast
articles.summary:
In late January a new social media site took a certain corner of the internet by storm. Moltbook was conceived as a space where AI assistants could let off steam, chat and compare notes on their bosses, but it quickly became the focus of breathless claims that the singularity had arrived as the bots started badmouthing their humans and plotting an uprising. So what’s the truth about Moltbook? Madeleine Finlay hears from Aisha Down about what it tells us about AI, and about us.

<

While ecologists believe invasive species play a major role in more than 60% of plant and animal extinctions, stopping them in their tracks is almost impos

articles.title: Are we hard-wired for infidelity?
articles.summary:
Monogamy may be held up as an ideal, but evolution has other ideas

Most of us know people in committed relationships, even lifelong marriages. And we also know stories about relationship transgressions, of partnerships tested or broken by infidelity.

As an evolutionary biologist who studies sex and relationships, I’m fascinated by these two truths. We humans make romantic commitments to each other – and some also break those commitments by cheating.

articles.title: Sugary drinks linked to rising anxiety in teens
articles.summary: Sugary drinks may be linked to more than just physical health problems in teens. A new review of multiple studies found a consistent association between high consumption of beverages like soda, energy drinks, sweetened juices, and flavored milks and increased anxiety symptoms in adolescents.
articles.original_description: Sugary drinks may be linked to more than just physical health problems in teens. A new review of multiple studies found a consistent association between high consumption of beverages like soda, energy drinks, sweetened juices, and flavored milks and increased anxiety symptoms in adolescents.

articles.title: Intermittent fasting fails to beat standard dieting for weight loss
articles.summary: Intermittent fasting has become one of the most talked-about weight loss trends in recent years, promising dramatic results with simple changes to when you eat. But a major Cochrane review suggests the reality may be far less exciting. After analyzing 22 clinical trials involving nearly 2,000 adults, researchers found that intermittent fasting did not produce significantly more weight loss than standard diet advice or even no structured plan at all.

articles.title: Ancient microbes may have used oxygen 500 million years before it filled Earth’s atmosphere
articles.summary: Life on Earth may have learned to breathe oxygen long before oxygen filled the skies. MIT researchers traced a key oxygen-processing enzyme back hundreds of millions of years before the Great Oxidation Event. Early microbes living near oxygen-producing cyanobacteria may have quickly used up the gas as it formed, slowing its rise in the atmosphere. The results suggest life was adapting to oxygen far earlier — and far more creatively — than once thought.

articles.title: A spinning gyroscope could finally unlock ocean wave energy
articles.summary: Ocean waves are a vast and steady source of renewable energy, but capturing their power efficiently has long frustrated engineers. A researcher at The University of Osaka has now explored a bold new approach: a gyroscopic wave energy converter that uses a spinning flywheel inside a floating structure to turn wave motion into electricity. By harnessing gyroscopic precession—the subtle wobble of a spinning object under force—the system can be tuned to absorb energy across a wide range of wave cond

articles.title: The Moon is still shrinking and it could trigger more moonquakes
articles.summary: Researchers have uncovered more than a thousand previously unknown tectonic ridges across the Moon’s dark plains, showing the Moon is still contracting and reshaping itself. These features are among the youngest geological structures on the lunar surface. Because they form through the same forces linked to past moonquakes, they could signal new seismic hotspots.

articles.title: People who switched to cannabis drinks cut their alcohol use nearly in half
articles.summary: A new University at Buffalo study suggests cannabis-infused beverages could help some people cut back on alcohol. In a survey of cannabis users, those who drank cannabis beverages reported cutting their weekly alcohol intake roughly in half and binge drinking less often. Nearly two-thirds said they reduced or stopped drinking alcohol after starting cannabis drinks.

articles.title: A satellite illusion hid the true scale of Arctic snow loss
articles.summary: For years, satellite data suggested that autumn snow cover in the Northern Hemisphere was actually increasing — a surprising twist in a warming world. But a new analysis reveals that this apparent growth was an illusion caused by improving satellite technology that became better at detecting thin snow over time. In reality, snow cover has been shrinking by about half a million square kilometers per decade.

articles.title: Viagra and shingles vaccine show surprising promise against Alzheimer’s
articles.summary: Новое исследование выявило потенциал трех известных лекарств – препарата от эректильной дисфункции Виагры (силденафила), вакцины от опоясывающего лишая и рилузола – в борьбе с болезнью Альцгеймера. Вакцина от опоясывающего лишая (Zostavax) показала наибольшую перспективность среди проанализированных 80 препаратов для возможного повторного применения в лечении нейродегенеративного заболевания.
articles.original_description: A major new study has spotlighted three familiar medicines that could take on an unexpected new role in the fight against Alzheimer’s disease — with a shingles vaccine emerging as the front-runner. After reviewing 80 existing drugs, an international panel of experts identified Zostavax, Viagra (sildenafil), and riluzole as the most promising candidates for repurposing.

articles.title: Toxic metals found in bananas after Brazil mining disaster
articles.summary: Исследование показало, что после крупного горнодобывающего происшествия в Бразилии токсичные металлы, такие как свинец и кадмий, попадают в пищевые культуры. В частности, бананы, маниока и какао показали повышенное содержание этих элементов, что представляет потенциальную опасность для детей до шести лет, а также вызывает опасения относительно долгосрочного воздействия на здоровье взрослых.
articles.original_description: Researchers investigating crops grown in soil contaminated by the 2015 mining disaster in Brazil discovered that toxic metals are moving from the earth into edible plants. Bananas, cassava, and cocoa were found to absorb elements like lead and cadmium, with bananas showing a potential health risk for children under six. Although adults face lower immediate danger, scientists warn that long-term exposure could carry cumulative health consequences.

articles.title: Ancient DNA solves 12,000-year-old mystery of rare genetic growth disorder
articles.summary: An Ice Age double burial in Italy has yielded a stunning genetic revelation. DNA from a mother and daughter who lived over 12,000 years ago shows that the younger had a rare inherited growth disorder, confirmed through mutations in a key bone-growth gene. Her mother carried a milder version of the same mutation. The finding not only solves a long-standing mystery but also proves that rare genetic diseases stretch far back into prehistory.

articles.title: Ultra-fast pulsar found near the Milky Way’s supermassive black hole
articles.summary: Scientists scanning the heart of the Milky Way have spotted a tantalizing signal: a possible ultra-fast pulsar spinning every 8.19 milliseconds near Sagittarius A*, the supermassive black hole at our galaxy’s core. Pulsars act like incredibly precise cosmic clocks, and finding one in this extreme environment could open a rare window into how space-time behaves under intense gravity.

articles.title: NASA fired three rockets into the northern lights and the results are stunning
articles.summary: NASA has pulled off a high-flying aurora investigation, launching three rockets into the glowing northern lights over Alaska. One mission targeted mysterious dark patches called black auroras, while the twin GNEISS rockets created a 3D scan of the aurora’s electrical currents. All rockets reached their planned altitudes and returned strong data. The result: an unprecedented look at how these dazzling light shows are wired from space to sky.

articles.title: 125 million-year-old dinosaur with never before seen hollow spikes discovered in China
articles.summary: A 125-million-year-old dinosaur just rewrote what we thought we knew about prehistoric life. Scientists in China have uncovered an exceptionally preserved juvenile iguanodontian with fossilized skin so detailed that individual cells are still visible. Even more astonishing, the plant-eating dinosaur was covered in hollow, porcupine-like spikes—structures never before documented in any dinosaur.

articles.title: Breakthrough CRISPR system could reverse antibiotic resistance crisis
articles.summary: Ученые из UC San Diego разработали новый CRISPR-инструмент, способный обратить вспять устойчивость бактерий к антибиотикам. Технология распространяет генетическую "исправку" в бактериальных популяциях, включая устойчивые к антибиотикам биопленки, что может стать прорывом в борьбе с надвигающейся глобальной угрозой антибиотикорезистентности.
articles.original_description: Antibiotic resistance is racing toward a global crisis, with “superbugs” projected to cause over 10 million deaths annually by 2050. Now, scientists at UC San Diego have unveiled a powerful new CRISPR-based tool that doesn’t just fight resistant bacteria—it can actively strip away their drug resistance. Inspired by gene drives used in insects, the technology spreads a genetic “fix” through bacterial populations, even inside stubborn biofilms that shield microbes from antibiotics.

articles.title: Climate change is accelerating but nature is slowing down
articles.summary: As the planet warms, many expected ecosystems to change faster and faster. Instead, a massive global study shows that species turnover has slowed by about one-third since the 1970s. Nature’s constant reshuffling appears to be driven more by internal ecological dynamics than by climate alone. The slowdown may signal something alarming: ecosystems losing the biodiversity needed to keep their engines running.

The slowdown may signal something alarming: ecosystems losing the biodiversity needed to keep their engines running.

articles.title: Mysterious RNA led scientists to a hidden layer of cancer
articles.summary: A mysterious RNA found in breast cancer led scientists to uncover an entire hidden class of cancer-specific RNAs across dozens of tumor types. These molecules form unique molecular signatures that identify cancer type and subtype with remarkable accuracy. Some even drive tumor growth and metastasis. Because many are released into the bloodstream, a simple blood test can track how patients respond to treatment and predict survival.

articles.title: Majorana qubits decoded in quantum computing breakthrough
articles.summary: Ученые разработали новый метод считывания состояний кубитов Майораны, которые обладают устойчивостью к помехам. Исследование подтвердило защищенность этих кубитов и продемонстрировало когерентность на уровне миллисекунд, что приближает создание надежных квантовых компьютеров.
articles.original_description: Scientists have developed a new way to read the hidden states of Majorana qubits, which store information in paired quantum modes that resist noise. The results confirm their protected nature and show millisecond scale coherence, bringing robust quantum computers closer to reality.

articles.title: Nearly 200,000 people reveal the real key to heart health
articles.summary: A decades-long study of nearly 200,000 adults challenges the low-carb versus low-fat debate. Both eating patterns were tied to lower heart disease risk when they emphasized whole grains, plant-based foods, and healthy fats. Versions filled with refined carbs and animal fats increased risk instead. Quality, not just quantity, appears to make the difference.

articles.title: This reengineered HPV vaccine trains T cells to hunt down cancer
articles.summary: Исследователи из Northwestern разработали переработанную вакцину против ВПЧ, которая значительно усиливает иммунный ответ на опухоли, вызванные вирусом.  Изменение расположения фрагмента белка ВПЧ в нановакцине на основе ДНК привело к более эффективному уничтожению раковых клеток T-клетками, замедлению роста опухолей и увеличению продолжительности жизни в лабораторных моделях.
articles.original_description: Northwestern researchers have shown that when it comes to cancer vaccines, arrangement can be just as important as ingredients. By repositioning a small fragment of an HPV protein on a DNA-based nanovaccine, the team dramatically strengthened the immune system’s attack on HPV-driven tumors. One specific design slowed tumor growth, extended survival in animal models, and unleashed far more cancer-killing T cells than other versions made with the exact same components.

articles.title: Lab grown human spinal cord heals after injury in major breakthrough
articles.summary: Ученые создали в лаборатории миниатюрный человеческий спинной мозг, имитирующий травматическое повреждение. Эксперименты показали, что обработка "танцующими молекулами" способствует восстановлению нервных волокон и уменьшению образования рубцовой ткани, что открывает перспективы для разработки методов лечения повреждений спинного мозга.
articles.original_description: Researchers have built a realistic human mini spinal cord in the lab and used it to simulate traumatic injury. The model reproduced key damage seen in real spinal cord injuries, including inflammation and scar formation. After treatment with fast moving “dancing molecules,” nerve fibers began growing again and scar tissue shrank. The results suggest the therapy could eventually help repair spinal cord damage.

articles.title: Mexico moves to combat pollution following Guardian investigations

Эти меры включают штрафы в размере 4,8 млн долларов для предприятия и внедрение новой системы мониторинга качества воздуха.

It was a bright morning in August 2022 when Ángel Montenegro was taken. A 31-year-old construction worker, Montenegro had been out all night drinking with some work buddies in the city of Cuautla and was waiting for a bus back to nearby Cuernavaca, where he lived.

At about 10am, a white van pulled up: several men jumped out and dragged Montenegro and a co-worker inside before speeding off.

articles.title: ‘A cry of pain from every player’: the new reality of Ukraine’s musicians
articles.summary: Украинские музыканты продолжают создавать произведения, отражающие трагедию войны, в пятый год конфликта. Композитор Анна Корсун в своем произведении "Terricone" выражает боль и разрушения, вызванные войной, используя метафору отвалов угольной промышленности Донбасса. Музыка становится способом борьбы за свободу и сохранения национальной идентичности.
articles.original_description:
As the war enters its fifth terrible year, Ukrainian musicians continue to fight for freedom with music-making that is urgent and vital

It starts with a literal scream, a cry of pain from every player in the orchestra. The Ukrainian composer Anna Korsun’s piece Terricone is one of the most shattering creative acts of the war that began four years ago this month. articles.title: Javier Bardem and Tilda Swinton among those to condemn Berlinale’s ‘silence’ on Gaza
articles.summary:
At least 80 film-makers and stars sign open letter after German festival jury president Wim Wenders says they should keep out of politics

More than 80 current and former participants of the Berlinale, including Javier Bardem, Tilda Swinton and Adam McKay have signed an open letter condemning the festival’s “silence” on Gaza.

It comes after the film festival was swept up in what it called a “media storm” over the alleged sidelining of political discourse at the event.

articles.summary:
• American wins third gold overall and first since 2018

  • Shiffrin more than a second ahead of Rast in silver

With one last chance to break her ­barren Olympic run stretching back eight years, Mikaela ­Shiffrin ­delivered in style. The 30-year-old American surged to victory in the women’s slalom on a sun-splashed Wednesday in the Dolomites with a two-run time of 1min 39.10sec, becoming the first US skier to win three Olympic gold medals.
